title: 受動形 (Passive Voice in News Context)

titleTranslations.pt: 受動形 (Voz Passiva em Contexto Jornalístico)

rule: Group 1 verbs: Drop -u, add -areru (書く→書かれる). Group 2 verbs: Drop -ru, add -rareru (見る→見られる). Irregular: する→される, 来る→来られる
explanation: The passive voice is extensively used in news reporting to focus on events rather than who performed the action. It creates objectivity and formality typical of journalistic writing. Formation: Verb stem + れる/られる for present/future, れた/られた for past.

explanations.de: Das Passiv wird ausgiebig in der Nachrichtenberichterstattung verwendet, um sich auf Ereignisse zu konzentrieren statt auf die Person, die die Handlung ausgeführt hat. Es schafft Objektivität und Formalität, die typisch für journalistisches Schreiben ist. Bildung: Verbstamm + れる/られる für Gegenwart/Zukunft, れた/られた für Vergangenheit.
explanations.pt: A voz passiva é extensivamente usada em reportagens jornalísticas para focar nos eventos ao invés de quem realizou a ação. Cria objetividade e formalidade típica da escrita jornalística. Formação: Radical do verbo + れる/られる para presente/futuro, れた/られた para passado.

title: 必要がある
rule: Verb dictionary form + 必要がある/必要がない. Can also be used with noun + の + 必要がある. Examples: 確認する必要がある (it's necessary to confirm), 準備の必要がある (there's a need for preparation).
explanation: Expresses necessity in a more formal, objective way - 'it is necessary to' or 'there is a need to'. This pattern emphasizes the existence of a need rather than personal obligation. Often used in formal contexts, business writing, or when discussing general requirements.

explanations.de: Drückt Notwendigkeit auf eine formalere, objektivere Weise aus - 'es ist notwendig zu' oder 'es gibt eine Notwendigkeit zu'. Dieses Muster betont die Existenz einer Notwendigkeit anstatt persönlicher Verpflichtung. Oft in formalen Kontexten, Geschäftskorrespondenz oder bei der Diskussion allgemeiner Anforderungen verwendet.
explanations.pt: Expressa necessidade de uma forma mais formal e objetiva - 'é necessário' ou 'há necessidade de'. Este padrão enfatiza a existência de uma necessidade ao invés de obrigação pessoal. Frequentemente usado em contextos formais, escrita empresarial ou ao discutir requisitos gerais.

title: 敬語の使い分け
rule: 尊敬語: お/ご + verb stem + になる, special verbs (いらっしゃる, 召し上がる). 謙譲語: お/ご + verb stem + する, special verbs (申し上げる, いただく). 丁寧語: verb + です/ます
explanation: Proper usage distinction of keigo (honorific language): 尊敬語 (respectful) for others' actions, 謙譲語 (humble) for your actions, 丁寧語 (polite) for general courtesy. Essential for appropriate social communication

explanations.de: Angemessene Verwendungsunterscheidung von Keigo (Höflichkeitssprache): 尊敬語 (respektvoll) für Handlungen anderer, 謙譲語 (bescheiden) für eigene Handlungen, 丁寧語 (höflich) für allgemeine Höflichkeit. Wesentlich für angemessene soziale Kommunikation.
explanations.pt: Distinção de uso adequado do keigo (linguagem honorífica): 尊敬語 (respeitoso) para ações de outros, 謙譲語 (humilde) para suas ações, 丁寧語 (polido) para cortesia geral. Essencial para comunicação social apropriada

title: ～ことがある
rule:
Verb (present/past tense) + ことがある
Examples: 行くことがある (sometimes go), 行ったことがある (have been/experienced going)
explanation: Expresses occasional experience or occurrence - 'sometimes' or 'there are times when.' Used to describe experiences that happen from time to time, not regularly. Can also express past experience when used with past tense verb + ことがある.

explanations.de: Drückt gelegentliche Erfahrung oder Auftreten aus - 'manchmal' oder 'es gibt Zeiten, in denen.' explanations.pt: Expressa experiência ou ocorrência ocasional - 'às vezes' ou 'há vezes quando'. Usado para descrever experiências que acontecem de vez em quando, não regularmente. Também pode expressar experiência passada quando usado com verbo no passado + ことがある.

rule: Verb dictionary form + ことになる / Verb ない form + ことになる (for negative)
explanation: It has been decided/arranged that...; to be decided that something will happen. This pattern indicates that a decision has been made (often by others or circumstances) that will result in a particular outcome. It emphasizes the result of a decision rather than who made it.

title: ～だろう/でしょう（推量）
rule: Verb plain form + だろう/でしょう, i-adj + だろう/でしょう, na-adj + だろう/でしょう, noun + だろう/でしょう
explanation: Probability and conjecture about future events. Used to express what the speaker thinks will probably happen, with だろう being more casual and でしょう more polite. Essential for discussing future possibilities and making predictions.

explanations.de: Wahrscheinlichkeit und Vermutung über zukünftige Ereignisse. Wird verwendet, um auszudrücken, was der Sprecher denkt, wird wahrscheinlich passieren, wobei だろう legerer und でしょう höflicher ist. Wesentlich für die Diskussion zukünftiger Möglichkeiten und das Treffen von Vorhersagen.
explanations.pt: Probabilidade e conjectura sobre eventos futuros. Usado para expressar o que o falante acha que provavelmente acontecerá, com だろう sendo mais casual e でしょう mais polido. Essencial para discutir possibilidades futuras e fazer previsões.

title: Integration of all N4 change and decision patterns

titleTranslations.pt: Integração de todos os padrões N4 de mudança e decisão

rule: Combines: Verb + ようになる/なくなる + Verb + ことにする/なる + たほうがいい + conditional forms (もし + たら) + て-form sequences for narrative flow
explanation: This lesson integrates all previously learned patterns for expressing changes, decisions, advice, and transitions. Students practice combining ようになる/なくなる (gradual change), ことにする/なる (decisions), たほうがいい (advice), and conditional forms in natural conversation contexts. The focus is on smooth transitions between patterns and appropriate usage in extended discourse about personal life changes.

explanations.de: Diese Lektion integriert alle zuvor gelernten Muster zum Ausdruck von Veränderungen, Entscheidungen, Ratschlägen und Übergängen. Schüler üben die Kombination von ようになる/なくなる (allmähliche Veränderung), ことにする/なる (Entscheidungen), たほうがいい (Ratschlag) und konditionalen Formen in natürlichen Gesprächskontexten über persönliche Lebensveränderungen.
explanations.pt: Esta lição integra todos os padrões previamente aprendidos para expressar mudanças, decisões, conselhos e transições. Os alunos praticam combinar ようになる/なくなる (mudança gradual), ことにする/なる (decisões), たほうがいい (conselho), e formas condicionais em contextos de conversação naturais sobre mudanças na vida pessoal. O foco está em transições suaves entre padrões e uso apropriado em discurso estendido sobre mudanças na vida pessoal.

title: Invitation and Response Patterns
rule: Invitation: Verb stem + ませんか / いっしょに + activity + ませんか. Accept: いいですね / ぜひ + acceptance. Decline: すみません + reason + んです
explanation: Complete patterns for making invitations, accepting, and declining. Includes: ～ませんか (invitation), いいですね (positive response), すみません + reason (polite decline), and appropriate follow-up expressions. These patterns allow for complete invitation exchanges in Japanese.

explanations.de: Vollständige Muster für Einladungen, Annahme und Ablehnung. Beinhaltet: ～ませんか (Einladung), いいですね (positive Antwort), すみません + Grund (höfliche Ablehnung) und angemessene Folgeausdrücke. Diese Muster ermöglichen vollständige Einladungsaustausche auf Japanisch.
explanations.pt: Padrões completos para fazer convites, aceitar e recusar. Inclui: ～ませんか (convite), いいですね (resposta positiva), すみません + razão (recusa educada), e expressões de acompanhamento apropriadas. Esses padrões permitem trocas completas de convites em japonês.

title: Noun modification with relative clauses

titleTranslations.pt: Modificação de substantivo com orações relativas

rule: [Descriptive clause] + [Noun] - The descriptive clause uses plain form verbs/adjectives and directly precedes the noun
explanation: Basic relative clauses allow you to describe or modify nouns by adding descriptive information. In Japanese, the modifying clause comes before the noun it describes, without using particles like 'which' or 'that' as in English. This pattern is essential for creating more detailed and precise descriptions.

explanations.de: Grundlegende Relativsätze ermöglichen es, Substantive zu beschreiben oder zu modifizieren, indem beschreibende Informationen hinzugefügt werden. Im Japanischen kommt der modifizierende Satz vor dem Substantiv, das er beschreibt, ohne Partikel wie 'welcher' oder 'das' wie im Deutschen zu verwenden. Dieses Muster ist wesentlich für detailliertere und präzisere Beschreibungen.
explanations.pt: Orações relativas básicas permitem descrever ou modificar substantivos adicionando informações descritivas. Em japonês, a oração modificadora vem antes do substantivo que ela descreve, sem usar partículas como 'que' ou 'qual' como em português. Este padrão é essencial para criar descrições mais detalhadas e precisas.

explanation: Comprehensive integration of all planning expressions learned in this unit: つもりです, 予定です, ことにしました, ようと思います, volitional form + よう. title: Potential Form (られる/える)
rule: Group 1 (u-verbs): Change final う sound to え sound + る (たべる→たべられる becomes たべれる in casual speech). Group 2 (ru-verbs): Drop る + られる (たべる→たべられる). Irregular: する→できる, くる→こられる. The resulting form conjugates like a regular Group 2 verb.
explanation: The potential form expresses ability or possibility to do something. It's the Japanese equivalent of 'can/be able to' in English. Unlike できる which works with nouns, the potential form is created directly from verbs and shows what actions someone is capable of performing. This form is essential for expressing personal abilities and asking about others' capabilities.

explanations.de: Die Potentialform drückt Fähigkeit oder Möglichkeit aus, etwas zu tun. Sie ist das japanische Äquivalent von 'können/imstande sein' im Deutschen. Im Gegensatz zu できる, das mit Substantiven funktioniert, wird die Potentialform direkt von Verben gebildet und zeigt, welche Handlungen jemand ausführen kann. Diese Form ist wesentlich, um persönliche Fähigkeiten auszudrücken und nach den Fähigkeiten anderer zu fragen.
explanations.pt: A forma potencial expressa habilidade ou possibilidade de fazer algo. É o equivalente japonês de 'poder/ser capaz de' em português. Diferente de できる que funciona com substantivos, a forma potencial é criada diretamente dos verbos e mostra que ações alguém é capaz de realizar. Esta forma é essencial para expressar habilidades pessoais e perguntar sobre as capacidades dos outros.

title: Review and application of change expressions

titleTranslations.pt: Revisão e aplicação de expressões de mudança

rule: Various patterns: Verb dictionary form + ようになる, Verb negative + なくなる, Verb + ことにする, Verb + ことになる. These can be combined in complex sentences to describe multi-faceted life changes.
explanation: This lesson reviews and combines the change expressions learned in previous lessons: ようになる/なくなる (gradual change), ことにする (personal decision), and ことになる (external decision). Students practice using these patterns together to describe complex life transitions that involve both gradual changes and decisive moments.

explanations.de: Diese Lektion überprüft und kombiniert die in vorherigen Lektionen gelernten Veränderungsausdrücke: ようになる/なくなる (allmähliche Veränderung), ことにする (persönliche Entscheidung) und ことになる (externe Entscheidung). Schüler üben, diese Muster zusammen zu verwenden, um komplexe Lebensübergänge zu beschreiben, die sowohl allmähliche Veränderungen als auch entscheidende Momente beinhalten.
explanations.pt: Esta lição revisa e combina as expressões de mudança aprendidas em lições anteriores: ようになる/なくなる (mudança gradual), ことにする (decisão pessoal), e ことになる (decisão externa). Os alunos praticam usar esses padrões juntos para descrever transições de vida complexas que envolvem tanto mudanças graduais quanto momentos decisivos.

rule:

explanation: Expresses that someone has come to do something or has developed the ability/habit to do something. This pattern indicates a gradual change or development of a new ability, habit, or state. It emphasizes the process of change rather than the final result.

explanations.de: Drückt aus, dass jemand dazu gekommen ist, etwas zu tun oder die Fähigkeit/Gewohnheit entwickelt hat, etwas zu tun. Dieses Muster zeigt eine allmähliche Veränderung oder Entwicklung einer neuen Fähigkeit, Gewohnheit oder eines Zustands an. Es betont den Prozess der Veränderung anstatt des Endergebnisses.
explanations.pt: Expressa que alguém passou a fazer algo ou desenvolveu a habilidade/hábito de fazer algo. Este padrão indica uma mudança gradual ou desenvolvimento de uma nova habilidade, hábito ou estado. Enfatiza o processo de mudança em vez do resultado final.

patterns: Verb dictionary form + ようになる

rule: もし + Verb/Adjective たら + advice statement. The たら form shows a conditional relationship, while もし emphasizes the hypothetical nature.
explanation: Review of conditional patterns used when giving advice that depends on specific situations. もし adds emphasis to hypothetical situations, making advice more nuanced and contextual. Used with たら form to express 'if... then you should...'

explanations.de: Wiederholung konditionaler Muster, die beim Geben von Ratschlägen verwendet werden, die von spezifischen Situationen abhängen. もし fügt Betonung zu hypothetischen Situationen hinzu und macht Ratschläge nuancierter und kontextueller. Verwendet mit たら-Form, um 'wenn... dann solltest du...' auszudrücken.
explanations.pt: Revisão de padrões condicionais usados ao dar conselhos que dependem de situações específicas. もし adiciona ênfase a situações hipotéticas, tornando os conselhos mais nuançados e contextuais. Usado com a forma たら para expressar 'se... então você deveria...'

title: volitional form (~よう)
rule: Group 1: -u verbs → -ou (読む→読もう) | Group 2: -ru verbs → stem + -you (食べる→食べよう) | Irregular: する→しよう, 来る→こよう
explanation: The volitional form expresses intention, suggestion, or invitation to do something together. It can mean 'let's do...' when used with others, or 'I will/shall do...' when expressing one's own intention. Formation varies by verb group: Group 1 verbs change the final -u sound to -ou, Group 2 verbs add -you to the stem, and irregular verbs have special forms (する→しよう、来る→こよう).

explanations.de: Die Volitionalform drückt Absicht, Vorschlag oder Einladung aus, etwas zusammen zu tun. Sie kann 'lass uns...' bedeuten, wenn sie mit anderen verwendet wird, oder 'ich werde/soll...' beim Ausdrücken der eigenen Absicht. Die Bildung variiert je nach Verbgruppe: Gruppe-1-Verben ändern den End-u-Laut zu -ou, Gruppe-2-Verben fügen -you zum Stamm hinzu, und unregelmäßige Verben haben spezielle Formen (する→しよう、来る→こよう).
explanations.pt: A forma volitiva expressa intenção, sugestão ou convite para fazer algo juntos. Pode significar 'vamos fazer...' quando usado com outros, ou 'eu vou/farei...' ao expressar a própria intenção. A formação varia por grupo de verbos: verbos do Grupo 1 mudam o som final -u para -ou, verbos do Grupo 2 adicionam -you ao radical, e verbos irregulares têm formas especiais (する→しよう、来る→こよう).

title: ~つもりです
rule: Verb plain form + つもりです | Negative: Verb ない form + つもりです
explanation: Expresses a firm intention or plan to do something in the future. Unlike simple future tense, つもりです indicates a deliberate decision or resolution. It shows the speaker's determination to carry out an action and is more definitive than just expressing possibility.

explanations.de: Drückt eine feste Absicht oder einen Plan aus, etwas in der Zukunft zu tun. Im Unterschied zur einfachen Zukunftsform zeigt つもりです eine bewusste Entscheidung oder einen Vorsatz an. Es zeigt die Entschlossenheit des Sprechers, eine Handlung auszuführen und ist definitiver als nur die Äußerung einer Möglichkeit.
explanations.pt: Expressa uma intenção firme ou plano de fazer algo no futuro. Diferentemente do tempo futuro simples, つもりです indica uma decisão deliberada ou resolução. Mostra a determinação do falante em executar uma ação e é mais definitivo do que apenas expressar possibilidade.

title: 〜が痛いです
rule: [Body part] + が + 痛いです / [Body part] + が + 痛い (casual)
explanation: Used to express that a specific body part hurts or is in pain. The が particle marks the body part that is experiencing pain. This is the standard polite way to describe physical discomfort in Japanese.

explanations.de: Wird verwendet, um auszudrücken, dass ein bestimmter Körperteil schmerzt oder Schmerzen hat. Das が-Partikel markiert den Körperteil, der Schmerzen empfindet. Dies ist die standardmäßige höfliche Art, körperliche Beschwerden auf Japanisch zu beschreiben.
explanations.pt: Usado para expressar que uma parte específica do corpo dói ou está com dor. A partícula が marca a parte do corpo que está sentindo dor. Esta é a forma educada padrão para descrever desconforto físico em japonês.

title: 〜ことにしました
rule: Verb (dictionary form) + ことにしました / Verb (ない form) + ことにしました
explanation: Expresses that the speaker has decided to do something. This pattern shows a conscious decision made by the speaker, often after consideration. The decision is presented as final and definite.

explanations.de: Drückt aus, dass der Sprecher sich entschieden hat, etwas zu tun. Dieses Muster zeigt eine bewusste Entscheidung des Sprechers, oft nach Überlegung. Die Entscheidung wird als endgültig und definitiv dargestellt.
explanations.pt: Expressa que o falante decidiu fazer algo. Este padrão mostra uma decisão consciente tomada pelo falante, muitas vezes após consideração. A decisão é apresentada como final e definitiva.

title: 〜そうだ (expressing impressions/hearsay)
rule: For appearance: Verb stem + そうだ / i-adj (without い) + そうだ / na-adj + そうだ. For hearsay: Plain form + そうだ
explanation: Used to express impressions based on appearance or hearsay information. When attached to i-adjectives (without い) or verb stems, it means 'seems/looks like'. When used with だ/である, it means 'I heard that' or 'apparently'.

explanations.de: Wird verwendet, um Eindrücke basierend auf dem Aussehen oder Informationen vom Hörensagen auszudrücken. Wenn es an i-Adjektive (ohne い) oder Verbstämme angehängt wird, bedeutet es 'scheint/sieht aus wie'. Wenn es mit だ/である verwendet wird, bedeutet es 'Ich habe gehört, dass' oder 'anscheinend'.
explanations.pt: Usado para expressar impressões baseadas na aparência ou informações de terceiros. Quando anexado a adjetivos-i (sem い) ou radicais verbais, significa 'parece/tem a aparência de'. Quando usado com だ/である, significa 'ouvi dizer que' ou 'aparentemente'.

title: 〜つもりです
rule: Verb dictionary form + つもりです / Verb ない form + つもりです
explanation: Expresses a firm intention or plan that the speaker has decided to carry out. This pattern shows the speaker's strong personal intention, different from scheduled plans. Formation uses dictionary form + つもりです for positive intentions, or ない form + つもりです for negative intentions (things you don't intend to do).

explanations.de: Drückt eine feste Absicht oder einen Plan aus, den der Sprecher zu verwirklichen beschlossen hat. Dieses Muster zeigt die starke persönliche Absicht des Sprechers, unterschiedlich von geplanten Terminen. Bildung verwendet Grundform + つもりです für positive Absichten oder ない-Form + つもりです für negative Absichten (Dinge, die man nicht zu tun beabsichtigt).
explanations.pt: Expressa uma intenção firme ou plano que o falante decidiu executar. Este padrão mostra a forte intenção pessoal do falante, diferente de planos agendados. A formação usa forma de dicionário + つもりです para intenções positivas, ou forma ない + つもりです para intenções negativas (coisas que você não pretende fazer).

title: 〜ている（習慣）
rule: Verb て-form + いる/います. For habitual meaning: Action verbs that describe repeated activities rather than ongoing states. Examples: 勉強している (studying regularly), 通っている (attending regularly).
explanation: Present progressive for habitual actions - indicates ongoing states or regularly repeated actions. Different from the continuous aspect ている, this usage describes habits, routines, and regular activities. Essential for describing daily school life and consistent behaviors.

explanations.de: Verlaufsform für gewohnheitsmäßige Handlungen - zeigt andauernde Zustände oder regelmäßig wiederholte Handlungen an. explanations.pt: Presente progressivo para ações habituais - indica estados contínuos ou ações regularmente repetidas. Diferente do aspecto contínuo ている, este uso descreve hábitos, rotinas e atividades regulares. Essencial para descrever a vida escolar diária e comportamentos consistentes.

rule: Te-form + しまいました. Examples: 食べてしまいました, 忘れてしまいました, 壊してしまいました
explanation: Expresses that an action has been completed, often with a sense of regret, disappointment, or finality. When used with negative events, it shows that something unfortunate happened completely. Can also show that something was done thoroughly or accidentally.

explanations.de: Drückt aus, dass eine Handlung abgeschlossen wurde, oft mit einem Gefühl von Bedauern, Enttäuschung oder Endgültigkeit. Bei negativen Ereignissen zeigt es, dass etwas Unglückliches vollständig geschehen ist. Kann auch zeigen, dass etwas gründlich oder versehentlich getan wurde.
explanations.pt: Expressa que uma ação foi completada, frequentemente com um sentimento de arrependimento, decepção ou finalidade. Quando usado com eventos negativos, mostra que algo infeliz aconteceu completamente. Também pode mostrar que algo foi feito completamente ou acidentalmente.

title: あげる vs くれる

titleTranslations.de: あげる vs くれる
titleTranslations.pt: あげる vs くれる

rule:
あげる: [Giver は] [Receiver に] [Object を] あげる
くれる: [Giver が] [Receiver に] [Object を] くれる
explanation: These verbs both mean 'to give' but differ based on social perspective. あげる is used when the speaker or their in-group gives to others, while くれる is used when others give to the speaker or their in-group. This reflects Japanese social awareness and in-group/out-group distinctions.

explanations.de: Diese Verben bedeuten beide 'geben', unterscheiden sich aber basierend auf der sozialen Perspektive. あげる wird verwendet, wenn der Sprecher oder dessen Gruppe anderen gibt, während くれる verwendet wird, wenn andere dem Sprecher oder dessen Gruppe geben. Dies spiegelt das japanische soziale Bewusstsein und die Unterscheidung zwischen Eigengruppe und Fremdgruppe wider.
explanations.pt: Estes verbos significam 'dar' mas diferem baseados na perspectiva social. あげる é usado quando o falante ou seu grupo interno dá a outros, enquanto くれる é usado quando outros dão ao falante ou seu grupo interno. Isto reflete a consciência social japonesa e distinções entre grupo interno/externo.

title: たことがある
rule: Verb in た-form + ことがある. For negative experiences, use たことがない (have never done). The particle が is essential and cannot be replaced with を.
explanation: Experience pattern meaning 'have done/experienced something before'. Used to express that someone has had a particular experience at some point in the past, without specifying when exactly it happened. This pattern emphasizes the fact that the experience exists rather than when it occurred.

explanations.de: Erfahrungsmuster mit der Bedeutung 'etwas schon einmal getan/erlebt haben'. Wird verwendet, um auszudrücken, dass jemand eine bestimmte Erfahrung irgendwann in der Vergangenheit gemacht hat, ohne genau anzugeben, wann es passiert ist. Dieses Muster betont die Tatsache, dass die Erfahrung existiert, nicht wann sie aufgetreten ist.
explanations.pt: Padrão de experiência que significa 'já fez/experimentou algo antes'. Usado para expressar que alguém teve uma experiência particular em algum momento no passado, sem especificar exatamente quando aconteceu. Este padrão enfatiza o fato de que a experiência existe ao invés de quando ocorreu.

title: たほうがいい
rule: Verb past tense + ほうがいい (positive advice) / Verb negative form + ほうがいい (negative advice). Examples: 食べたほうがいい (should eat), 食べないほうがいい (shouldn't eat)
explanation: Used to give advice or recommendations, meaning 'it would be better to...' or 'should...'. This pattern expresses what the speaker thinks is the best course of action for the listener. For positive advice, use the past tense form of the verb + ほうがいい. For negative advice (suggesting not to do something), use the negative form + ほうがいい.

explanations.de: Wird verwendet, um Ratschläge oder Empfehlungen zu geben, bedeutet 'es wäre besser zu...' oder 'sollte...'. Dieses Muster drückt aus, was der Sprecher für die beste Vorgehensweise für den Zuhörer hält. Für positive Ratschläge verwendet man die Vergangenheitsform des Verbs + ほうがいい. Für negative Ratschläge (empfehlen, etwas nicht zu tun) verwendet man die Verneinungsform + ほうがいい.
explanations.pt: Usado para dar conselhos ou recomendações, significando 'seria melhor...' ou 'deveria...'. Este padrão expressa o que o falante pensa ser o melhor curso de ação para o ouvinte. Para conselhos positivos, use a forma passada do verbo + ほうがいい. Para conselhos negativos (sugerindo não fazer algo), use a forma negativa + ほうがいい.

explanation.pt: Usado para dar conselhos ou recomendações, significando 'seria melhor...' ou 'deveria...'. Este padrão expressa o que o falante pensa ser o melhor curso de ação para o ouvinte. Para conselhos positivos, use a forma passada do verbo + ほうがいい. Para conselhos negativos (sugerindo não fazer algo), use a forma negativa + ほうがいい.

title: たら
rule: Verb た-form + ら. For い-adjectives: drop い + かったら. For な-adjectives/nouns: だったら. Examples: 食べたら (if you eat), 高かったら (if it's expensive), 元気だったら (if you're healthy)
explanation: Conditional form expressing 'if/when' scenarios. Used to give advice, make suggestions, or describe hypothetical situations. Different from other conditional forms as it emphasizes completion of the first action before the second occurs. Commonly used in advice-giving contexts.

explanations.de: Konditionalform, die 'wenn/falls' Szenarien ausdrückt. Wird verwendet, um Ratschläge zu geben, Vorschläge zu machen oder hypothetische Situationen zu beschreiben. Unterscheidet sich von anderen Konditionalformen dadurch, dass es die Vollendung der ersten Handlung vor der zweiten betont. Wird häufig in Ratschlägen verwendet.
explanations.pt: Forma condicional expressando cenários de 'se/quando'. Usado para dar conselhos, fazer sugestões ou descrever situações hipotéticas. title: つもりです
rule: Verb dictionary form + つもりです / Verb negative form + つもりです
explanation: Intention or plan to do something. Expresses what the speaker intends or plans to do in the future. More definite than 予定 (schedule) and indicates personal volition and determination.

rule: Verb in て-form + あげる. For example: 手伝ってあげる (help someone), 教えてあげる (teach someone)
explanation: Expresses doing an action for someone else as a favor or kindness. Used when the speaker or someone in their in-group does something for another person. Emphasizes the giver's perspective and kindness.

title: できる
rule: Verb dictionary form + ことができる (formal) OR Noun + ができる (casual)
explanation: Expresses ability, capability, or possibility to do something. When used with other verbs, it shows that the speaker has the skill or capacity to perform that action. It can also indicate that something is ready, completed, or available.

explanations.de: Drückt Fähigkeit, Können oder Möglichkeit aus, etwas zu tun. Wenn es mit anderen Verben verwendet wird, zeigt es, dass der Sprecher die Fertigkeit oder Kapazität hat, diese Handlung auszuführen. Es kann auch anzeigen, dass etwas fertig, vollständig oder verfügbar ist.

title: でしょう
rule: Verb/adjective + でしょう / Used after volitional form for suggestions: 行こうでしょう (though often just 行きませんか is preferred)
explanation: でしょう is used to make suggestions, express probability, or soften statements. When used with the volitional form or in questions, it makes suggestions more polite and tentative. It can mean 'probably', 'I suppose', or be used to invite agreement or make gentle suggestions.

explanations.de: でしょう wird verwendet, um Vorschläge zu machen, Wahrscheinlichkeit auszudrücken oder Aussagen abzuschwächen. Wenn es mit der Volitionalform oder in Fragen verwendet wird, macht es Vorschläge höflicher und tentativ. Es kann 'wahrscheinlich', 'ich nehme an' bedeuten oder verwendet werden, um Zustimmung einzuladen oder sanfte Vorschläge zu machen.
explanations.pt: でしょう é usado para fazer sugestões, expressar probabilidade ou suavizar declarações. Quando usado com a forma volitiva ou em perguntas, torna as sugestões mais educadas e hesitantes. Pode significar 'provavelmente', 'eu suponho', ou ser usado para convidar concordância ou fazer sugestões gentis.

title: ないほうがいい
rule: Verb ない-form + ほうがいい. Remove the い from ない and add ほうがいい directly.
explanation: Should not/had better not. Negative advice pattern used to recommend against doing something. Very common in health contexts to advise what to avoid. Stronger than だめです or いけません.

explanations.de: Sollte nicht/besser nicht. Negatives Ratschlagsmuster, das verwendet wird, um davon abzuraten, etwas zu tun. Sehr häufig in Gesundheitskontexten, um zu raten, was man vermeiden sollte. Stärker als だめです oder いけません.
explanations.pt: Não deveria/seria melhor não. Padrão de conselho negativo usado para recomendar contra fazer algo. Muito comum em contextos de saúde para aconselhar o que evitar. Mais forte que だめです ou いけません.

title: に particle with giving/receiving
rule: [Giver] は [Recipient] に [Object] を [Giving/Receiving verb]
explanation: The に particle marks the recipient in giving and receiving expressions. It indicates the direction of the giving action - who receives the item. This is essential for proper sentence structure with giving and receiving verbs.

explanations.de: Das に-Partikel markiert den Empfänger in Geben- und Erhalten-Ausdrücken. Es zeigt die Richtung der Gebehandlung an - wer den Gegenstand erhält. Dies ist wesentlich für die richtige Satzstruktur bei Geben- und Erhalten-Verben.
explanations.pt: A partícula に marca o destinatário nas expressões de dar e receber. Indica a direção da ação de dar - quem recebe o item. Isso é essencial para a estrutura adequada da frase com verbos de dar e receber.

title: のが上手です
rule: Verb dictionary form + のが + 上手です/上手だ
explanation: Expresses that someone is good at or skillful in a particular activity. Used to compliment others' abilities. The の nominalizes the verb, making it the subject of the sentence with が particle.

explanations.de: Drückt aus, dass jemand gut oder geschickt in einer bestimmten Aktivität ist. Wird verwendet, um die Fähigkeiten anderer zu loben. Das の nominalisiert das Verb und macht es zum Subjekt des Satzes mit が-Partikel.
explanations.pt: Expressa que alguém é bom ou habilidoso em uma atividade particular. Usado para elogiar as habilidades de outros. O の nominaliza o verbo, tornando-o o sujeito da frase com a partícula が.

title: ほうがいい
rule: Verb た-form + ほうがいい (positive advice) OR Verb ない-form + ほうがいい (negative advice). For i-adjectives: adjective + ほうがいい. For na-adjectives: adjective な + ほうがいい.
explanation: Should/had better/it would be better to. This pattern gives strong recommendations or advice, stronger than たらいいです. Used when the speaker believes the action is clearly beneficial or necessary. Can be used with both positive and negative forms to give advice about what to do or avoid.

explanations.de: Sollte/besser/es wäre besser zu. Dieses Muster gibt starke Empfehlungen oder Ratschläge, stärker als たらいいです. Wird verwendet, wenn der Sprecher glaubt, dass die Handlung eindeutig vorteilhaft oder notwendig ist. Kann sowohl mit positiven als auch negativen Formen verwendet werden, um Ratschläge darüber zu geben, was zu tun oder zu vermeiden ist.
explanations.pt: Deveria/seria melhor/é melhor. Este padrão dá recomendações ou conselhos fortes, mais forte que たらいいです. Usado quando o falante acredita que a ação é claramente benéfica ou necessária. Pode ser usado com formas positivas e negativas para dar conselhos sobre o que fazer ou evitar.

title: もらう
rule: [Receiver は] [Giver に/から] [Object を] もらう
explanation: To receive or get something from someone. Unlike giving verbs, もらう focuses on the receiver's action. It's often used with から or に to indicate who gave the item. This verb is more neutral in terms of social perspective compared to あげる/くれる.

explanations.de: Etwas von jemandem erhalten oder bekommen. Im Gegensatz zu Verben des Gebens konzentriert sich もらう auf die Handlung des Empfängers. Es wird oft mit から oder に verwendet, um anzuzeigen, wer das Objekt gegeben hat. Dieses Verb ist in Bezug auf die gesellschaftliche Perspektive neutraler als あげる/くれる.
explanations.pt: Receber ou ganhar algo de alguém. Ao contrário dos verbos de dar, もらう foca na ação do receptor. É frequentemente usado com から ou に para indicar quem deu o item. Este verbo é mais neutro em termos de perspectiva social comparado a あげる/くれる.

rule: 体の調子 + が + いいです/悪いです/よくないです

title: 受身形 (passive voice)
rule: Ru-verbs: 食べる → 食べられる, 見る → 見られる. U-verbs: 読む → 読まれる, 書く → 書かれる. Irregular: する → される, 来る → 来られる
explanation: The passive voice in Japanese expresses that someone or something receives an action rather than performing it. It emphasizes what happened to the subject rather than who did the action. Formation: verb stem + られる (ru-verbs) or verb stem + れる (u-verbs). Often used to describe unfortunate events that happened to you.

explanations.de: Das Passiv im Japanischen drückt aus, dass jemand oder etwas eine Handlung empfängt, anstatt sie auszuführen. Es betont, was mit dem Subjekt geschehen ist, anstatt wer die Handlung ausgeführt hat. Bildung: Verbstamm + られる (ru-Verben) oder Verbstamm + れる (u-Verben). Oft verwendet, um unglückliche Ereignisse zu beschreiben, die einem widerfahren sind.
explanations.pt: A voz passiva em japonês expressa que alguém ou algo recebe uma ação em vez de realizá-la. Enfatiza o que aconteceu com o sujeito em vez de quem fez a ação. Formação: radical do verbo + られる (verbos ru) ou radical do verbo + れる (verbos u). Frequentemente usado para descrever eventos infelizes que aconteceram com você.

title: 差し上げる
rule: Object + を + 差し上げる / Object + を + 差し上げます (polite form)
explanation: Humble form of あげる (to give) - used when the speaker gives something to someone of higher social status. This shows respect to the recipient by lowering the speaker's position. Essential for proper workplace and formal communication.

explanations.de: Bescheidene Form von あげる (geben) - verwendet, wenn der Sprecher jemandem mit höherem sozialen Status etwas gibt. Dies zeigt Respekt gegenüber dem Empfänger, indem die Position des Sprechers erniedrigt wird. Wesentlich für angemessene Arbeitsplatz- und formelle Kommunikation.

title: 意志形 (volitional form) + よう
rule: る-verbs: stem + よう (食べる→食べよう) / う-verbs: change to ou-sound + う (行く→行こう, 読む→読もう) / Irregular: する→しよう, 来る→来よう
explanation: The volitional form expresses intention, determination, or suggestions. It conveys 'let's do', 'I will do', or 'I intend to do'. Formation varies by verb type: る-verbs drop る and add よう (食べる→食べよう), う-verbs change final sound to ou sound (行く→行こう), irregular verbs have special forms (する→しよう, 来る→来よう).

explanations.de: Die Volitiv-Form drückt Absicht, Entschlossenheit oder Vorschläge aus. Sie vermittelt 'lass uns tun', 'ich werde tun' oder 'ich beabsichtige zu tun'. Bildung variiert je nach Verbtyp: る-Verben lassen る fallen und fügen よう hinzu (食べる→食べよう), う-Verben ändern den Endlaut zu ou-Laut (行く→行こう), unregelmäßige Verben haben spezielle Formen (する→しよう, 来る→来よう).
explanations.pt: A forma volitiva expressa intenção, determinação ou sugestões. Transmite 'vamos fazer', 'eu farei' ou 'eu pretendo fazer'. A formação varia por tipo de verbo: verbos ru removem る e adicionam よう (食べる→食べよう), verbos u mudam o som final para som ou (行く→行こう), verbos irregulares têm formas especiais (する→しよう, 来る→来よう).

A formação varia por tipo de verbo: verbos ru removem る e adicionam よう (食べる→食べよう), verbos u mudam o som final para som ou (行く→行こう), verbos irregulares têm formas especiais (する→しよう, 来る→来よう).

title: Foreign word adaptation patterns

titleTranslations.pt: Padrões de adaptação de palavras estrangeiras

rule: Common patterns: 1) 'r' and 'l' sounds become 'r' in Japanese, 2) Final consonants get vowel sounds added, 3) 'f' sounds often become 'h', 4) Long vowels marked with ー, 5) 'th' sounds become 's' or 'z'
explanation: When foreign words enter Japanese, they undergo systematic sound changes to fit Japanese phonetics. This includes adding vowels to break up consonant clusters, lengthening certain vowels, and replacing sounds that don't exist in Japanese with similar ones.

explanations.de: Wenn Fremdwörter ins Japanische eindringen, durchlaufen sie systematische Lautveränderungen, um zur japanischen Phonetik zu passen. Dies beinhaltet das Hinzufügen von Vokalen, um Konsonantenhäufungen aufzubrechen, das Verlängern bestimmter Vokale und das Ersetzen von Lauten, die im Japanischen nicht existieren, durch ähnliche.
explanations.pt: Quando palavras estrangeiras entram no japonês, elas passam por mudanças sonoras sistemáticas para se adequar à fonética japonesa. Isso inclui adicionar vogais para quebrar grupos de consoantes, alongar certas vogais e substituir sons que não existem em japonês por similares.

explanation: The five fundamental vowel sounds in Japanese that form the basis of all hiragana pronunciation. These vowels are: あ (a), い (i), う (u), え (e), お (o). Unlike English, Japanese vowels have consistent, unchanging pronunciation regardless of context.

title: Katakana syllable structure
rule: Each katakana character corresponds to a hiragana equivalent. ア=あ, カ=か, サ=さ, etc. Long vowels use the dash mark ー (e.g., コーヒー). Foreign consonant clusters are broken up with vowels (e.g., 'coffee' becomes ko-o-hi-i).
explanation: Katakana follows the same syllable patterns as hiragana, with each character representing one mora (sound unit). The angular, geometric shapes distinguish it from the curved hiragana characters. Key differences include the use of long vowel marks (ー) and combinations for sounds not native to Japanese.

explanations.de: Katakana folgt denselben Silbenmustern wie Hiragana, wobei jedes Zeichen eine Mora (Lauteinheit) repräsentiert. Die eckigen, geometrischen Formen unterscheiden es von den geschwungenen Hiragana-Zeichen. Wichtige Unterschiede beinhalten die Verwendung von Langvokalzeichen (ー) und Kombinationen für Laute, die im Japanischen nicht heimisch sind.
explanations.pt: Katakana segue os mesmos padrões silábicos do hiragana, com cada caractere representando uma mora (unidade sonora). As formas angulares e geométricas o distinguem dos caracteres hiragana curvos. Diferenças principais incluem o uso de marcas de vogal longa (ー) e combinações para sons não nativos do japonês.

title: Mixed tense usage in conversation

titleTranslations.pt: Uso de tempo misto em conversa

rule: Combine different tense forms: Verb-ます (present/future), Verb-た (past), Verb-ている (ongoing), Verb-たい (want to)
explanation: The ability to naturally switch between present, past, and future tenses within a conversation to express when different events occurred. This involves using た-form for past actions, present forms for current states, and future expressions for planned actions.

explanations.de: Die Fähigkeit, natürlich zwischen Gegenwarts-, Vergangenheits- und Zukunftszeiten innerhalb eines Gesprächs zu wechseln, um auszudrücken, wann verschiedene Ereignisse aufgetreten sind. Dies beinhaltet die Verwendung der た-Form für vergangene Handlungen, Gegenwartsformen für aktuelle Zustände und Zukunftsausdrücke für geplante Handlungen.
explanations.pt: A habilidade de alternar naturalmente entre tempos presente, passado e futuro dentro de uma conversa para expressar quando diferentes eventos ocorreram. Isso envolve usar forma た para ações passadas, formas presentes para estados atuais e expressões futuras para ações planejadas.

examples.english: I went to the hospital yesterday. Yes, it was a bit difficult.

examples.english: I will go to school tomorrow. Then, I will meet with friends.
examples.japanese: あしたがっこうにいきます。それから、ともだちとあいます。

title: Past tense with transportation (で + いきました)

titleTranslations.de: Vergangenheitsform mit Verkehrsmitteln (で + いきました)
titleTranslations.pt: Passado com transporte (で + いきました)

rule: Transportation method + で + destination + に/へ + いきました. Example: でんしゃで がっこうに いきました (I went to school by train). The で particle marks the means of transportation.
explanation: This pattern combines the particle で (indicating means/method) with past tense movement verbs to describe how someone traveled to a destination in the past. The で particle shows the method of transportation used, while いきました indicates the completed action of going. This construction is essential for sharing travel experiences and explaining how you reached different places.

explanations.de: Dieses Muster kombiniert das Partikel で (das Mittel/Methode anzeigt) mit Bewegungsverben in der Vergangenheitsform, um zu beschreiben, wie jemand in der Vergangenheit zu einem Ziel gereist ist. Das で-Partikel zeigt das verwendete Verkehrsmittel an, während いきました die abgeschlossene Handlung des Gehens anzeigt. Diese Konstruktion ist wesentlich, um Reiseerfahrungen zu teilen und zu erklären, wie man verschiedene Orte erreicht hat.
explanations.pt: Este padrão combina a partícula で (indicando meio/método) com verbos de movimento no passado para descrever como alguém viajou para um destino no passado. A partícula で mostra o método de transporte usado, enquanto いきました indica a ação completada de ir. Esta construção é essencial para compartilhar experiências de viagem e explicar como você chegou a diferentes lugares.

title: Polite agreement and disagreement expressions

titleTranslations.pt: Expressões educadas de concordância e discordância

rule: Agreement: たしかに/そうですね + elaboration; Disagreement: ちょっと/でも + alternative view
explanation: Appropriate ways to show agreement (たしかに、そうですね) or gentle disagreement (ちょっと、でも) in polite conversation. These expressions help maintain harmony while expressing different viewpoints.

explanations.de: Angemessene Arten, Zustimmung (たしかに、そうですね) oder sanften Widerspruch (ちょっと、でも) in höflicher Konversation zu zeigen. Diese Ausdrücke helfen dabei, Harmonie zu bewahren, während verschiedene Standpunkte ausgedrückt werden.
explanations.pt: Formas apropriadas de mostrar concordância (たしかに、そうですね) ou discordância gentil (ちょっと、でも) em conversas educadas. Essas expressões ajudam a manter a harmonia enquanto expressam diferentes pontos de vista.

title: Question word + か + 分かります/知っています

titleTranslations.de: Fragewort + か + 分かります/知っています
titleTranslations.pt: Palavra interrogativa + か + 分かります/知っています

rule: Question word (何/どこ/いつ/etc.) + か + verb of knowing/understanding
explanation: Used to politely ask if someone knows information about something. This pattern combines question words with か to create indirect questions, making them more polite and less direct than simple question word queries.

explanations.de: Wird verwendet, um höflich zu fragen, ob jemand Informationen über etwas weiß. Dieses Muster kombiniert Fragewörter mit か, um indirekte Fragen zu erstellen, was sie höflicher und weniger direkt macht als einfache Fragewort-Abfragen.
explanations.pt: Usado para perguntar educadamente se alguém sabe informações sobre algo. Este padrão combina palavras interrogativas com か para criar perguntas indiretas, tornando-as mais educadas e menos diretas do que simples consultas com palavras interrogativas.

rule: Question word (何/誰/どこ/etc.) + でも + rest of sentence
explanation: Even/any + question word - creates statements meaning 'anything/anyone/anywhere is fine' or 'no matter what/who/where'. Used to express that any option within the category is acceptable.

explanations.pt: Mesmo/qualquer + palavra interrogativa - cria declarações significando 'qualquer coisa/qualquer pessoa/qualquer lugar está bem' ou 'não importa o quê/quem/onde'. Usado para expressar que qualquer opção dentro da categoria é aceitável.

title: Verb た-form (past tense)
rule: Remove ます from present tense and add ました. Examples: たべます → たべました (ate), いきます → いきました (went), みます → みました (saw). For irregular verbs: きます → きました (came), します → しました (did).
explanation: The た-form expresses completed actions in the past. It is the polite past tense form created by changing the ます-form ending to ました. This form indicates that an action or state occurred and finished before the present moment. Essential for narrating past experiences, describing what you did during trips, and talking about completed activities.

explanations.de: Die た-Form drückt abgeschlossene Handlungen in der Vergangenheit aus. Es ist die höfliche Vergangenheitsform, die durch Änderung der ます-Form-Endung zu ました erstellt wird. Diese Form zeigt an, dass eine Handlung oder ein Zustand vor dem gegenwärtigen Moment aufgetreten und beendet ist. Wesentlich für das Erzählen vergangener Erfahrungen, das Beschreiben dessen, was man während Reisen getan hat, und das Sprechen über abgeschlossene Aktivitäten.
explanations.pt: A forma た expressa ações completadas no passado. É a forma educada do passado criada mudando a terminação da forma ます para ました. Esta forma indica que uma ação ou estado ocorreu e terminou antes do momento presente. Essencial para narrar experiências passadas, descrever o que você fez durante viagens e falar sobre atividades completadas.

rule: Change verb to て-form, then add the next verb in て-form, continuing the chain. The final verb shows the tense for the entire sequence.
explanation: Connect multiple actions in sequence using て-form. This pattern allows you to describe a series of actions that happen one after another, creating natural flowing sentences. The て-form acts as a connector, similar to 'and' in English, but specifically for verbs in sequence.

explanations.de: Verbinde mehrere Aktionen in Reihenfolge mit der て-Form. Dieses Muster ermöglicht es dir, eine Reihe von Aktionen zu beschreiben, die nacheinander geschehen, und natürlich fließende Sätze zu erstellen. Die て-Form fungiert als Verbindung, ähnlich wie 'und' im Deutschen, aber spezifisch für Verben in Sequenz.
explanations.pt: Conecte múltiplas ações em sequência usando a forma て. Este padrão permite descrever uma série de ações que acontecem uma após a outra, criando frases que fluem naturalmente. rule:
[Thing]が + すき/きらい + です
Example: コーヒーが すき です (I like coffee)
explanation: The が particle marks the object of emotion when used with preference words like すき (like) and きらい (dislike). Unlike を which marks direct objects of action, が marks what triggers the emotion. This is because すき and きらい are adjectives describing a state of feeling rather than verbs describing actions.

explanations.de: Das Partikel が markiert das Objekt der Emotion, wenn es mit Vorliebenwörtern wie すき (mögen) und きらい (nicht mögen) verwendet wird. Im Gegensatz zu を, das direkte Objekte von Handlungen markiert, markiert が das, was die Emotion auslöst. Dies liegt daran, dass すき und きらい Adjektive sind, die einen Gefühlszustand beschreiben, und keine Verben, die Handlungen beschreiben.
explanations.pt: A partícula が marca o objeto de emoção quando usada com palavras de preferência como すき (gostar) e きらい (não gostar). Isso acontece porque すき e きらい são adjetivos descrevendo um estado de sentimento ao invés de verbos descrevendo ações.

title: それから
rule: Sentence 1. それから、Sentence 2. (Note: can be used at the beginning of a new sentence or to connect clauses)
explanation: A conjunction meaning 'and then', 'after that', or 'furthermore'. Used to connect sentences and ideas in a logical sequence, allowing speakers to build longer, more connected discourse. Essential for creating natural-sounding self-introductions that flow smoothly from one topic to another.

explanations.de: Eine Konjunktion mit der Bedeutung 'und dann', 'danach' oder 'außerdem'. Wird verwendet, um Sätze und Ideen in einer logischen Reihenfolge zu verbinden, sodass Sprecher längere, zusammenhängendere Gespräche führen können. Wesentlich für natürlich klingende Selbstvorstellungen, die reibungslos von einem Thema zum anderen übergehen.
explanations.pt: Uma conjunção que significa 'e então', 'depois disso', ou 'além disso'. Usada para conectar frases e ideias em uma sequência lógica, permitindo que os falantes construam discursos mais longos e conectados. Essencial para criar apresentações pessoais que soam naturais e fluem suavemente de um tópico para outro.

title: て-form + から
rule: Verb in て-form + から + main clause. The から here means 'after' when following a て-form verb.
explanation: After doing [action], [result/next action]. This pattern shows that one action is completed before another begins. It emphasizes the completion of the first action as a prerequisite for the second action.

explanations.de: Nachdem [Handlung] getan wurde, [Ergebnis/nächste Handlung]. Dieses Muster zeigt, dass eine Handlung abgeschlossen ist, bevor eine andere beginnt. Es betont die Vollendung der ersten Handlung als Voraussetzung für die zweite Handlung.

title: て-form basics

explanation: The て-form is the connecting form of verbs that allows you to link actions together. It shows that actions happen in sequence or are ongoing. This is one of the most important verb forms in Japanese as it enables describing multiple activities and their relationships.

title: で (action location particle)
rule: Place + で + action verb
explanation: The particle で indicates where an action takes place. It shows the location or means by which an action is performed. Unlike に which shows static location, で shows dynamic location where something happens.

explanations.pt: A partícula で indica onde uma ação acontece. Mostra o local ou meio pelo qual uma ação é realizada. Diferentemente de に que mostra localização estática, で mostra localização dinâmica onde algo acontece.

title: です/ます vs だ/である

titleTranslations.de: です/ます vs だ/である
titleTranslations.pt: です/ます vs だ/である

rule: Polite: Verb-ます, Adjective-です, Noun-です | Casual: Verb dictionary form, い-adjective alone, な-adjective/noun-だ
explanation: The fundamental difference between polite and casual speech in Japanese. です/ます forms show respect and formality, while だ/である forms are casual and used with close friends, family, or when speaking down in hierarchy. The choice depends on your relationship with the listener and the social situation.

explanations.de: Der grundlegende Unterschied zwischen höflicher und umgangssprachlicher Rede im Japanischen. です/ます Formen zeigen Respekt und Formalität, während だ/である Formen umgangssprachlich sind und mit engen Freunden, Familie oder beim Sprechen nach unten in der Hierarchie verwendet werden. Die Wahl hängt von Ihrer Beziehung zum Zuhörer und der sozialen Situation ab.
explanations.pt: A diferença fundamental entre fala educada e casual em japonês. As formas です/ます mostram respeito e formalidade, enquanto as formas だ/である são casuais e usadas com amigos próximos, família, ou quando falando de forma hierarquicamente inferior. A escolha depende do seu relacionamento com o ouvinte e da situação social.

rule: どう + [noun] + です + か / どんな + [noun] + です + か
explanation: How is...? / What kind of...? Used to ask for opinions, descriptions, or characteristics about people, places, or things. どう asks about state or opinion, while どんな asks about type or characteristics.

explanation: な-adjectives are descriptive words that require な when directly modifying nouns. Unlike い-adjectives, they cannot modify nouns directly and need the connecting particle な. They describe qualities, states, and characteristics.

explanation: The particle の creates possessive relationships, showing that something belongs to someone or is associated with someone. explanations.de: Das Partikel の schafft Besitzverhältnisse und zeigt, dass etwas jemandem gehört oder mit jemandem verbunden ist. title: へ (direction particle)
rule: [Destination] + へ + [movement verb]. Example: がっこうへ いきます (go toward school), とうきょうへ かえります (return toward Tokyo)
explanation: The particle へ indicates direction or destination, similar to に but with more emphasis on the direction of movement rather than the specific endpoint. It's often used in more formal or literary contexts and gives a sense of 'toward' a place.

explanations.de: Das Partikel へ zeigt Richtung oder Ziel an, ähnlich wie に, aber mit mehr Betonung auf die Bewegungsrichtung als auf den spezifischen Endpunkt. Es wird oft in formelleren oder literarischen Kontexten verwendet und vermittelt ein Gefühl von 'in Richtung' eines Ortes.
explanations.pt: A partícula へ indica direção ou destino, similar a に mas com mais ênfase na direção do movimento do que no ponto final específico. É frequentemente usada em contextos mais formais ou literários e transmite o sentido de 'em direção a' um lugar.

title: ます form verbs
rule: Verb stem + ます (e.g., たべる → たべます, のむ → のみます)
explanation: The polite form of verbs used in respectful conversation. This is the standard verb form for daily interactions and shows politeness to the listener. All Japanese verbs have a ます form that is created by taking the verb stem and adding ます. This form is essential for proper communication in Japanese society.

explanations.de: Die höfliche Form von Verben, die in respektvoller Unterhaltung verwendet wird. Dies ist die Standard-Verbform für tägliche Interaktionen und zeigt Höflichkeit gegenüber dem Zuhörer. Alle japanischen Verben haben eine ます-Form, die gebildet wird, indem man den Verbstamm nimmt und ます hinzufügt. Diese Form ist essentiell für angemessene Kommunikation in der japanischen Gesellschaft.
explanations.pt: A forma polida dos verbos usada em conversas respeitosas. Esta é a forma verbal padrão para interações diárias e demonstra polidez ao interlocutor. Todos os verbos japoneses têm uma forma ます que é criada pegando o radical do verbo e adicionando ます. Esta forma é essencial para uma comunicação adequada na sociedade japonesa.

title: も particle (also/too)
rule:
[Topic/Object]も + [rest of sentence]
Replaces は: たなかさんも がくせい です (Tanaka is also a student)
Replaces が: ラーメンも すき です (I also like ramen)
Replaces を: パンも かいます (I'll also buy bread)
explanation: The も particle means 'also' or 'too' and replaces は, が, and を particles to show that something applies to multiple things or people. It creates connections between similar statements and is essential for building conversations where you agree or add information.

explanations.de: Das も Partikel bedeutet 'auch' oder 'ebenfalls' und ersetzt は, が und を Partikel, um zu zeigen, dass etwas für mehrere Dinge oder Personen gilt. Es schafft Verbindungen zwischen ähnlichen Aussagen und ist essentiell für Gespräche, in denen man zustimmt oder Informationen hinzufügt.
explanations.pt: A partícula も significa 'também' e substitui as partículas は, が e を para mostrar que algo se aplica a múltiplas coisas ou pessoas. Ela cria conexões entre declarações similares e é essencial para construir conversas onde você concorda ou adiciona informações.

title: よろしく お願いします

titleTranslations.de: よろしく お願いします

rule: Used as a complete phrase at the end of introductions or when making requests. Can be shortened to just よろしく in casual situations.
explanation: A polite expression meaning 'please treat me favorably' or 'please look after me'. This is a crucial politeness formula used when meeting someone new, asking for help, or at the end of self-introductions. Shows respect and humility while requesting the other person's goodwill.

explanations.de: Ein höflicher Ausdruck, der 'bitte behandeln Sie mich wohlwollend' oder 'bitte kümmern Sie sich um mich' bedeutet. Dies ist eine wichtige Höflichkeitsformel, die verwendet wird, wenn man jemanden neu kennenlernt, um Hilfe bittet oder am Ende von Selbstvorstellungen. Zeigt Respekt und Demut, während man das Wohlwollen der anderen Person erbittet.
explanations.pt: Uma expressão polida que significa 'por favor, me trate bem' ou 'por favor, cuide de mim'. Esta é uma fórmula de polidez crucial usada ao conhecer alguém novo, pedir ajuda, ou ao final de apresentações pessoais. Demonstra respeito e humildade enquanto solicita a boa vontade da outra pessoa.

title: を + ください
rule: [Object] + を + ください
explanation: A polite way to request something, literally meaning 'please give me [object]'. This is the standard pattern for making polite requests in Japanese, especially when ordering food, buying items, or asking for services. The を particle marks the direct object being requested.

explanations.de: Eine höfliche Art, um etwas zu bitten, bedeutet wörtlich 'bitte geben Sie mir [Objekt]'. Dies ist das Standardmuster für höfliche Bitten auf Japanisch, besonders beim Bestellen von Essen, Kaufen von Artikeln oder Bitten um Dienstleistungen. Das を Partikel kennzeichnet das direkte Objekt, um das gebeten wird.

title: を particle with action verbs

titleTranslations.pt: partícula を com verbos de ação

rule: Subject は Object を Verb
explanation: The を particle marks the direct object of an action - the thing that receives the action of the verb. It shows what is being acted upon by the subject. Essential for expressing who does what to what in Japanese sentences.

explanations.de: Das を Partikel kennzeichnet das direkte Objekt einer Handlung - das Ding, das die Handlung des Verbs empfängt. Es zeigt, worauf vom Subjekt eingewirkt wird. Essentiell für den Ausdruck von 'wer tut was womit' in japanischen Sätzen.
explanations.pt: A partícula を marca o objeto direto de uma ação - a coisa que recebe a ação do verbo. Ela mostra sobre o que está sendo agido pelo sujeito. Essencial para expressar quem faz o que com o que em frases japonesas.

title: 何時 question pattern
rule: 何時ですか = What time is it? / いま何時ですか = What time is it now? Can also be used for scheduled times: レストランは何時ですか = What time is the restaurant?
explanation: 何時 (nanji) is used to ask 'what time?' It's the standard question word for asking about time and is typically used with です to form polite questions. This pattern is essential for time-related conversations and inquiries.

explanations.de: 何時 (nanji) wird verwendet, um 'wie spät?' zu fragen. Es ist das Standard-Fragewort für Zeitfragen und wird typischerweise mit です verwendet, um höfliche Fragen zu bilden. Dieses Muster ist essentiell für zeitbezogene Gespräche und Anfragen.
explanations.pt: 何時 (nanji) é usado para perguntar 'que horas?' É a palavra de pergunta padrão para perguntar sobre tempo e é tipicamente usada com です para formar perguntas polidas. Este padrão é essencial para conversas e perguntas relacionadas ao tempo.

title: 個・本・枚 counters
rule: Number + counter: いっこ (one small object), にほん (two long objects), さんまい (three flat objects)
explanation: Object counters are essential in Japanese for counting different types of items. 個 (ko) counts small round objects, 本 (hon) counts long thin objects, and 枚 (mai) counts flat objects. These counters attach to numbers to specify quantities precisely.

explanations.de: Objektzählwörter sind essentiell im Japanischen zum Zählen verschiedener Arten von Gegenständen. 個 (ko) zählt kleine runde Objekte, 本 (hon) zählt lange dünne Objekte, und 枚 (mai) zählt flache Objekte. Diese Zählwörter werden an Zahlen angehängt, um Mengen präzise anzugeben.
explanations.pt: Contadores de objetos são essenciais em japonês para contar diferentes tipos de itens. 個 (ko) conta objetos pequenos e redondos, 本 (hon) conta objetos longos e finos, e 枚 (mai) conta objetos planos. Estes contadores se anexam aos números para especificar quantidades precisamente.

title: 分 (fun/pun) counter
rule: Number + 分 = X minutes. Sound changes: 1分(ippun), 3分(sanpun), 6分(roppun), 8分(happun), 10分(juppun). Other numbers use 'fun': 2分(nifun), 4分(yonfun), 5分(gofun), etc.
explanation: The counter 分 is used with numbers to express minutes. It undergoes sound changes (rendaku) with certain numbers, becoming 'pun' after 1, 3, 6, 8, and 10. This counter is essential for precise time telling beyond just hours.

explanations.de: Das Zählwort 分 wird mit Zahlen verwendet, um Minuten auszudrücken. Es durchläuft Lautveränderungen (rendaku) bei bestimmten Zahlen und wird zu 'pun' nach 1, 3, 6, 8 und 10. Dieses Zählwort ist essentiell für präzise Zeitangaben über reine Stunden hinaus.
explanations.pt: O contador 分 é usado com números para expressar minutos. Ele sofre mudanças sonoras (rendaku) com certos números, tornando-se 'pun' após 1, 3, 6, 8 e 10. Este contador é essencial para dizer as horas precisamente além de apenas as horas.

title: 時 (ji) counter
rule: Number (1-12) + 時 = X o'clock. Examples: 1時 (ichiji), 2時 (niji), 3時 (sanji)... 12時 (juuniji)
explanation: The counter 時 is used with numbers to express hours when telling time. It follows the pattern: number + 時 = hour o'clock. This is the basic foundation for telling time in Japanese and is always used when stating what hour it is.

explanations.de: Das Zählwort 時 wird mit Zahlen verwendet, um Stunden bei der Zeitangabe auszudrücken. Es folgt dem Muster: Zahl + 時 = Uhr. Dies ist die grundlegende Basis für Zeitangaben im Japanischen und wird immer verwendet, wenn man angibt, welche Stunde es ist.
explanations.pt: O contador 時 é usado com números para expressar horas ao dizer as horas. Ele segue o padrão: número + 時 = hora em ponto. Esta é a base fundamental para dizer as horas em japonês e é sempre usado ao declarar que horas são.

title: 時間 + に + verb
rule: Specific time word + に + action verb. Examples: 7時に (at 7 o'clock), 朝に (in the morning), 月曜日に (on Monday)
explanation: Particle に is used to mark specific points in time when an action occurs. It indicates 'at' or 'on' a particular time. Used with specific times like clock times, days of the week, months, and years, but NOT with relative time expressions like 'today', 'now', or 'tomorrow'.

explanations.de: Das Partikel に wird verwendet, um spezifische Zeitpunkte zu kennzeichnen, wann eine Handlung stattfindet. Es zeigt 'um' oder 'an' einer bestimmten Zeit an. Wird mit spezifischen Zeiten wie Uhrzeiten, Wochentagen, Monaten und Jahren verwendet, aber NICHT mit relativen Zeitausdrücken wie 'heute', 'jetzt' oder 'morgen'.
explanations.pt: A partícula に é usada para marcar pontos específicos no tempo quando uma ação ocorre. Ela indica 'em' ou 'no' um momento particular. Usada com horários específicos como horários do relógio, dias da semana, meses e anos, mas NÃO com expressões de tempo relativo como 'hoje', 'agora' ou 'amanhã'.
